ContentStructure.title: By the end of this module, you should be able to:  Define technical drawing. Explain concepts of plan, section, elevation, axonometric and perspective. Explain the process of measuring  a room. List the rules of measurement. Describe how to draw a rough sketch of a room. Explain the concept of scale in a drawing. Describe the process of transforming a sketch into a finished floorplan.
The design phase includes what is commonly referred to as the Six-Step Design Sequence - a step-by-step process to design a room.
Let’s start by sketching a room because this is where you will begin when you are designing a real room. You’ll measure the dimensions of the room and then represent it through a drawing.
What is drawing in this context?

Have you seen builders share a drawing of the rooms layout in a new flat to their prospective buyers or the 3D layout of an upcoming mall on display in hoardings?  These are all examples of a technical drawing, commonly referred to as drawing.
A Technical Drawing is a plan drawn to scale to indicate the relative positioning of objects in a given space keeping in mind the actual directions.
Why do you need a technical drawing? Choose all that apply and click Submit.
Because it helps you convey design ideas to others.

answer.title: Because it helps you convey design ideas to others.

ContentStructure.title: Because it helps during the development of ideas for initial or preliminary plans.

answer.title: Because it helps during the development of ideas for initial or preliminary plans.

ContentStructure.title: Because it helps you identify the fixed and the variable components in your subject.

answer.title: Because it helps you identify the fixed and the variable components in your subject.

ContentStructure.title: Because eventually this is what you transform into a finished presentation showcasing your design to your client.

answer.title: Because eventually this is what you transform into a finished presentation showcasing your design to your client.

ContentStructure.title: You must answer the question before continuing.

ContentStructure.title: A technical drawing can be of the following types:
Match the following and click Submit.

question.text: Match the following and click Submit.

ContentStructure.title: A plan drawing shows what you would see if you sliced through the building horizontally, lifted off the top part and looked down. The \

is usually made just above the level of the window sills.   It includes significant amount of information on the design and construction, such as the position of the walls, doors, windows, stairs, appliances, equipments, cabinetry and built-in interior elements.

Note: Usually, you will need to make a separate plan for each storey of the building.  You can represent the solid part of the building which is cut through by shading or hatching.  To relate the information on the floor plan to other drawings such as elevation, section and detail drawing, you can use cross referencing symbols. .
A section drawing shows what you would see if you made a vertical cut through the building, took one half away, and looked into the other half.
Note: To show where you have made your cuts, you need to draw \
on your plans with arrows on the ends to show which way the section is looking.  For solid parts that are cut (such as walls, floors or roofs) you can shade the area.

An elevation shows what you would see if you looked straight  at the walls in a room.  You have separate elevation drawings for different walls.   Typical interior elevations show vertical locations of doors, windows and other openings, profiles of objects, connection to the floor, ceiling and adjacent objects, material information and vertical dimensions.

Axonometric means to measure along axes.  Therefore, an Axonometric drawing indicates the image of an object as it would appear from a skew direction so that it reveals more than one side in the same picture.

Perspective is a method of representing subjects in a drawing, in such a way that they seem to recede into distant space, and appear smaller the farther they are away from you.  In a perspective drawing, you need to draw  people and objects, such that they appear believable and proportionately correct.
What does the given drawing represent? Choose the best answer and click Submit.
You must answer the question before continuing.

ContentStructure.title: Now that you know what a technical drawing means, it’s time to get started with step one of the design sequence, which is to measure and sketch the room.  In this step you are going to examine the room, measure it, and make a rough sketch of it.  You are also going to record information about the room on the Room Condition Checklist.  Finally, you might take a few pictures of the room for reference and to further ensure accuracy.   The purpose of this activity is to enable you to draw an accurate finished floorplan.
To measure the room you need to measure the overall width and length of the room.

Tools you Need:  To measure the room you need a measuring tape. To record your measurements, you need a sharp pencil.  For paper, use the graph paper. The graph lines will help you draw relatively straight lines freehand. You can also use any plain white paper.  Since you can’t write on thin air, you’ll also need some sort of portable writing surface.
In the figure shown, the width of the room is indicated as 16'–0\
.   The symbol ' stands for feet and the symbol \
, or 16 feet zero inches.  The length of the room is 24'–2\
.  Always add the zero inches—0\
long—that is, 16 feet and ¼ inch—you can record this as 16'–0\
long—that is, 16 feet and ½ an inch —you can round the measurement up to 16'–1“.
After measuring the overall dimensions, it’s time to enter this information on your sketch pad. To do so, draw a large rectangle on the sheet.
On your sketch, ,write in the dimensions of th length and width by drawing arrows.

Note: The rectangle you sketch is just an approximation of the shape of the room. Draw it freehand preferably on a graph paper. The ruled lines on the paper will help guide you in drawing reasonably straight lines.

Which end of the room will you position toward the top of the page?  There is no exact rule on this, but most designers orient their sketches with the northern-most wall at the top of the page. By knowing which way is north, you can easily determine which way the windows are oriented toward the sun.   So, draw the sketch indicating north at the top. Obviously, this places the west wall to the left, the east wall to the right, and the south wall at the bottom.
Note: Maps are drawn with North positioned at the top. Therefore, this serves as a familiar frame of reference.
Here is a sketch that indicates the important features you’ll find in just about every room.
If a wall measures 19 feet and ½ an inch, which of the following options is a correct representation of the dimension on a sketch?
Incorrect - A wall that is 19 feet and ½ an inch, round the measurement up to 19'–1“. Click Next to continue.
You must answer the question before continuing.

ContentStructure.title: Typically, architectural drawings do not represent objects at their full size. Buildings are drawn much smaller than their true size, but with all the parts in the correct proportion to each other, just as in the real building. This is called drawing to scale.

Similarly, the drawing of a room should exactly duplicate the proportions of the real room. For example, if Wall A in the room is twice the length of Wall B, then the line representing Wall A in your floorplan should be twice the length of the line representing Wall B.
What scale should you use for your finished drawings?

The most common scale used by interior designers for residential spaces is one inch equals four feet. Another way to state this scale is that ¼-inch equals one foot.  This means that each foot in the room is represented by ¼-inch on the paper. On finished drawings, this scale is usually indicated with the notation—Scale: ¼\
. This is also known as quarter-inch scale.

Example: If a wall is four feet long, you represent it with a one inch long line . If a wall is eight feet long, you represent it with a line two inches long. If a wall is ten feet long, you represent it with a line 2½ inches long.
To make scale drawings on paper, you will need the following tools.
Drawing Board: The graph paper is placed on the drawing board while drawing. Therefore, it is essential that the drawing board is smooth and has straight edges that are exactly parallel.
T-square: The T-square is used to draw horizontal lines.

Scale: It includes a ruler, a triangle scale and a protractor. The ruler has divisions marked on it proportionate to standard actual distances - 1 :lo, 1 :20. 1 :50, 1: 100 etc. The triangle is used to draw vertical lines. You can also use the triangles to draw diagonal lines.
Pencils: Well-sharpened pencils 2H lead pencils are good for scale drawings. They make a clean, sharp line and don't smear easily.
Compass: A handy tool to have, though most drawings can be made without one as well.
Drawing pins or Masking Tape: You can use these to hold your drawing in place while you are working.

Line weight pertains to the thickness of your line. When you draft, you need to vary the thicknesses of your lines. Line weight is important because it differentiates the lines in your drawing according to their importance, making the drawing easier to read.

Varying Line Weight  Walls are the most important element in your drawing. Therefore, they need to be drawn the darkest (i.e., using a B pencil) and the thickest. You can use a B pencil for this purpose.  The next important element of the drawing is the furniture—which is drawn with medium weight lines.   Besides using different grade pencils to differentiate the darkness or lightness of your lines, you can also vary the line weight by adjusting the pressure of your pencil to the paper. Press harder when drawing walls. Ease up a little when drawing the furniture. Use a light touch when drafting the windows, plants, or the least important elements.
Here is a reference table for you highlighting the difference in line weights.
Play Video: How to Draw a Floorplan (Placeholder)
Which one of the following will you represent with the darkest and the thickest line in the drawing? Choose the best option and click Submit.
Incorrect - The correct answer is Walls. Click Next to continue.
You must answer the question before continuing.

ContentStructure.title: Advances are being made in the world of computers every day, and those advances are quickly passed along to the public. Computer hardware and software are developed and revised at a frenzied pace. We are constantly bombarded with advertisements for newer, faster, better products. While this can be overwhelming, it also means that there are now more products available to help you with your interior decorating projects. The more informed you are about these products, the better you’ll be able to make intelligent decisions about what you need—and what you don’t.

Many interior design programs and apps are fun to play with. They can help you visualize the projects you’re working on, so that you can get a clearer idea of how a kitchen would look with maple cabinets and a granite counter-top or how a living room would look with a particular furniture layout. With a little of your time and energy, you can even use this software to show your clients three-dimensional views of your room plans.

CAD or Computer-Aided Design programs are among the first computer programs developed for building designs. They help you create two-dimensional drawings of buildings and other objects, such as plans, elevations, and sections. You can design houses, furniture, industrial products—just about any object under the sun.   Today, these are highly advanced software programs that allow architects and engineers to construct and edit the design of a building on their computers, making changes on screen along the way, just as you make changes in a word-processing document.

If you are planning on using CAD software you’ll need to ensure the following specifications for your computer:  Minimum 1 GB RAM A high-end graphics card A fast processor A monitor large enough for you to see the fine details in a floor plan without squinting.
Note: Make sure that you read the specifications on the box of any software that you are planning to buy and that your computer system meets the minimum requirements.

The most well-known CAD program is called AutoCAD by Autodesk. Originally, AutoCAD was only a two-dimensional (2-D) program, but now it can create three-dimensional (3-D) renderings of a building plan. You can go back and forth and use either the 2-D program or the 3-D section.
SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS  Operates on Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows XP and Apple MAC OS X v10.8, OSX v10.7.2, OSX v10.6.8 Minimum: 3GB RAM Needs 6GB hard drive available Needs 2.5GB disk space available

Drawing Elements: The drawing you make in AutoCAD is comprised of “elements,” such as lines, arcs, circles, and text. These drawing elements are combined to create a floorplan, an object, or some other working drawing. Once you select an element, you can move it around and edit it, or add an existing drawing from a disk to the plan and edit that too.

Easy to Use: To use AutoCAD, you can use the same keyboard and direct the program using menus that work in the same general way as those in a word processing program. You can customize your screen through specific CAD menus and submenus.

Working with Layers: You can create other layers for doors, windows, lighting, furniture, etc. The advantage to layers is that each layer can be turned “off” and “on.” When in the “on” position, the layer is active and edits or additions can be made to the layer. When the layer is in the “off” position, the user won’t be able to see it on the screen or make changes to it. The advantage of this is that when you have a large, complex drawing with many drawing elements, it may be difficult to see where one element begins and another ends. When you turn off certain layers, you can concentrate only on specific drawing entities that you need to edit.

Drawing Elements: The drawing you make in AutoCAD is comprised of “elements,” such as lines, arcs, circles, and text. These drawing elements are combined to create a floorplan, an object, or some other working drawing. Once you select an element, you can move it around and edit it, or add an existing drawing from a disk to the plan and edit that too.

Forming Blocks: Once you have created an element (e.g., a chair) you can turn it into a “block.” Anywhere else on your drawing, if you need to insert the same chair, you can just insert this block and you will not have to recreate it from scratch, hence saving time.

AutoCAD is very useful for building and design professionals, because it allows them to accomplish work with unmatched speed and proficiency.   If you are very fluent with computers, this program will allow you to leap over several steps of the design process that become ruthlessly time-consuming and highly repetitive (such as drawing doors or plumbing fixtures), when you work with projects that have a large scope.
Depending on the orientation of the room you are sketching, you can orient your in any direction. Choose True or False and click Submit.
Incorrect - The answer is False. Click Next o continue.

ContentStructure.title: In this lesson you have learned that:   A Technical Drawing is a plan drawn to scale to indicate the relative positioning of objects in a given space keeping in mind the actual directions.  A technical drawing can be of the following types: plan, section, elevation, axonometric and perspective.  To measure the room you need to measure the overall width and length of the room.  As a standard practice, most designers orient their sketches with the northern-most wall at the top of the page.  Drawing a building much smaller than its true size, but with all the parts in the correct proportion to each other, just as in the real building is called drawing to scale.   To make scale drawings on paper, you need a drafting board, drafting pins or masking tape, graph paper, T-square, Scale Ruler and Pencils.  Line weight pertains to the thickness of your line.  CAD stands for Computer-Aided Design.  The most well-known CAD program is called AutoCAD by Autodesk.  You can use AutoCAD to create 2D and 3D renderings of a building plan.
